title: Vault Index File Naming Convention
details:
For the vault generate-index feature, the index files must be named exactly the same as their containing folder name. This aligns with Obsidian's "folder plugin" that automatically displays the index file when clicking on the folder name in the file explorer.

VAULT HIERARCHY STRUCTURE:
1. MBA (Top Parent/Root) â†’ main-index template
2. Program Level (e.g., "Electives", "Value Chain Management", "Managerial Economics and Business Analysis") â†’ program-index template
3. Course Level (e.g., "Leading Teams Developing as A Leader") â†’ course-index template
4. Class Level (e.g., "leading-teams-building-effective-team-cultures") â†’ class-index template
   - Resources/ â†’ Special folder at class level
5. Module Level â†’ module-index template
   - Live Session/ â†’ Special folder at module level
   - Case Studies/ â†’ Can appear at class or module level â†’ case-study-index template
6. Lesson Level â†’ lesson-index template

SPECIAL FOLDER HANDLING:
- "Case Studies" folder â†’ case-study-index template (can be at class or module level)
- "Live Session" folder â†’ live-session-note template (at module level)
- "Resources" folder â†’ resources-index template (at class level)

CONTENT ORGANIZATION WITHIN INDEX FILES:
When creating index files, analyze existing files in the folder to determine their placement within the index page:
- Check YAML frontmatter "template-type" field to categorize content
- Use filename patterns as fallback for content without metadata
- Group content by type: readings, videos, transcripts, assignments, case studies, etc.
- Apply appropriate icons and ordering based on content type
